reviews.author: Wen Han
reviews.comment_content:
The experiments in this lab is designed to complement the materials taught in PHYS 2022. These include:
-Measuring the speed of light
-Blackbody Radiation
-Electrical conductivity in solids
-The photoelectric effect
-Measurement of charge to mass ratio of an electron
-Measuring the de Broglie wavelength of an electron
-Balmer Series
-Radioactive decay
reviews.comment_grading: The grade for this course is strictly follows the university guidelines .As this is a lab course, a large number of students have similar overall scores. This implies that the difference between A+ and C- is within 10 points. Furthermore, students with different TAs are graded on the same curve. This means that students with strict TAs are guaranteed to perform worse than those with lenient TAs.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload for this course is fairly light. The lab reports can be easily completed within 30 minutes assuming you prepared your Excel files during the lab. Unlike PHYS 1115, the lab summaries are mandatory but are not too difficult to complete.

reviews.author: O
reviews.comment_content: The experiments quite related to the course, which is a usual practice, but the questions it asked in pre-lab don't really being taught in the lessons and you need to find answer in the lab manual or even in website.
reviews.comment_teaching:
The IAs are quite nice in my sessions and they are quite helpful.
They will answer your questions though you will more or less being deducted marks by the TAs.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading is quite fair although it is more strict than in the elementary laboratory courses Phys1113 and Phys1115.
You need to do a lot of work to got the report marks and when everyone write a nice report, it will be a bad idea for not doing so.
reviews.comment_workload:
This laboratory course got one credit but please don't think that the workload is just similar to that of Phys1113 and Phys1115.
You will need to write about 250 words lab report every lab you finished and also answered the pre-lab and post-lab questions.
It is quite demanding and please expect to work overnight if you are going to work it the night before the lab.
But the 3 credits lab course after this one is even more demanding so it is fair for being not a 3 cre one but I think it should be 2 cre lol.

reviews.author: PeterLin
reviews.title: Modern Physics Laboratory
reviews.comment_content:
MP1 Direct Measurement of the Speed of Light (two weeks)
MP2 Blackbody Radiation (two weeks)
MP3 Electrical Conduction in Solids (one week)
MP4 Photoelectric Effect (one week)
MP5 Charge-to-Mass Ratio of the Electron (one week)
MP6 Electron Diffraction (one week)
MP7 The Balmer Series of Hydrogen (one week)
MP8 Radioactive Decay and Radiation Absorption (one week)

All labs are completed offline and we submit our lab report & summary through canvas (ddl: one week after the lab). Each student is randomly paired and the group changes every two weeks.
reviews.comment_teaching: Instructor appears only in tutorials, and materials covered are nearly the same as 1113,1115 (error analysis, summary and so on).
reviews.comment_grading:
(i) lab performance (20%)
(ii) lab reports (65%)
(iii) summary (15%)
The TA told us that the group finishes at first get 10/10 for performance, and 1,2,3 points deduction for later groups (depending on you group's speed ranking, I didn't remember much the cut-off)

For the lab report, I mainly get points deducted in pre-lab questions as sometimes TA is strict in my rough calculation/explanation/plotting although questions asked are straightforward.

For the summary it's like 玄學 as I always attach a lot of figures /tables/formulas but get something like 17/21 while once I neglected all these things and got 21/21. Maybe it's somewhat similar to essay writing in LANG :P

I got around ~96.3/100, resulting in an A+. I think the grade is better than the online lab version of PHYS 1115 (as everyone scores high for lab report and performance and the grading scheme is also different).
reviews.comment_workload:
Like PHYS1113,1115, 1-cre is just a joke :p

This year we only need to submit summary for MP1,MP2,MP4,MP5,MP6, so the workload outside the lab is reduced a lot compared to previous years.

reviews.author: tdhvl
reviews.comment_content:
During this course, we perform 8 experiments:
- Measuring the speed of light ( 2 sessions)
- Blackbody Radiation (2 sessions)
- Electrical conductivity in solids
- The photoelectric effect
- Measurement of charge to mass ratio of an electron
- Measuring the de Broglie wavelength of an electron
- Balmer Series
- Radioactive decay
Although this course has a co-requisite which is PHYS 2022, some experiments are not related to the knowledge learned in PHYS 2022.

There is only one tutorial session which focus on error analysis techniques (similar to General Physics Laboratory courses) and introduce how to write a good summary.
reviews.comment_teaching:
There is no teaching at all since this is a laboratory course. At the beginning of each laboratory session, the technician will summarize the procedure, give instructions on how to handle the devices and remind the problems that it may encounter during the process.

If you encounter a problem or you suspect that something went wrong with your devices, you can ask the TA or the technician for assistance and they will help you handle the problems. According to my observation, this will not affect your scores, unless you rely on them too much.
reviews.comment_grading:
The score is calculated by 20% lab performance + 60% lab reports + 20% summary writing.

If you attend all laboratory sessions, the lowest lab score will not be counted to the final score. However, if you missed one session without justification, then the final score will be calculated from all sessions, including the sessions that you miss. This is similar to PHYS 1113/1115.

The mean of all scores (performance, report, summary) of all sessions are all high. However, you do not need to get nearly absolute scores to secure an A+. For reference, my final score is around 96 and I got an A+.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is rigorous for a one-credit course. The lab performance and report is similar to PHYS 1113/1115. However, after each experiment, you have to write a summary which is very time consuming. I spend around 4 hours writing each summary, yet I still cannot gain full mark in any summary.

reviews.author: Roy Sukjin Mun
reviews.title: Poorly Designed Lab Course
reviews.comment_content:
Three tutorial sessions (attendance is not not mandatory) in the first three weeks combined with the actual lab sessions that also begin in the first week of the semester:

Tutorial sessions (Professor Wang):
1. Course Syllabus
2. Scientific Graphing & Data analysis
3. Guideline for Lab Report+Summary

Lab sessions (TAs and IA):
1.Direct Measurement of the Speed of Light (two weeks)
2.Blackbody Radiation (two weeks)
3.Electrical Conduction in Solids (one week)
4.Photoelectric Effect (one week)
5.Charge-to-Mass Ratio of the Electron (one week)
6.Electron Diffraction (one week)
7.The Balmer Series of Hydrogen (one week)
8.Radioactive Decay and Radiation Absorption (one week)

Some of the pre-lab questions are poorly designed and are not related to the contents of the lab.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Students only get to see the TA and a technical assistant during the lab. There is essentially no teaching as the course was designed for students to explore and get a conceptual feel of the principles in modern physics by themselves. In the beginning of each lab, the TA will spend about 5 minutes to note some points to consider. However, most of the time his English will be incomprehensible (I could barely understand a thing from the TA in our section throughout the semester. Most other students also could not understand his English). He sometimes even speaks in Mandarin if he does not know the English words. It is therefore suggested to ask the IA for help if the assigned TA is not a fluent English speaker.

Professor Wang actively responds to questions during the tutorials, so it will be good to attend the tutorial sessions if the students have not previously taken/audited PHYS1113/PHYS1115.
reviews.comment_grading:
Final grade is based on the lab performance (20%) + lab reports (60%) + summary (20%).

The grading scale is lenient but unclear. Different TAs will grade the reports and summary with their own standards. As for how the lab performance is graded, I directly quote what I have been told by the TA AFTER the semester by email:

"The lab performance consist of 4 parts: Lab preparation& time arrangement, Team work&safety, Quality of work and Understanding of materials& problem solving. For the first two part, the average student will get full points. For the last two point, they will get 1.5 point for each one. For each session, only one or two group will be graded. More than 8/10 point because I have to make sure that their performance is really better than others. For those group, I usually ask them to write down their name .If I miss you even you write down your name."

The class was never told about this or writing down our names whatsoever (or maybe he did tell us, either in Mandarin or in his baffling English). Most labs in PHYS2023 are conducted in a dark room, and students have to draw the curtains and play around with the light inside. The TA was always outside the curtains and has never come to check my lab. Hence, my lab performance grade was consistently 8/10. In terms of this, I cannot tell how fair the performance grading was.

For reference, my final grade is:
Performance: 80%
Report: 93.9%
Summary: 94.5%
Final Grade: A

More details of the grading benchmarks for the lab report and performance are included as attachments below.
reviews.comment_workload:
Slightly rigorous workload. One lab report, pre-lab report coupled with a summary of the lab (min 300 words, max 450 words) are to be submitted at the beginning of lab session every week.

Some of the pre-lab questions are irrelevant to the contents of the actual lab (that happened to be the blackbody radiation and charge-to-mass ratio, if I recall correctly. Some required knowledge in astrophysics/solid state physics to answer fully). In these cases, students have to depend on external or online references to search for answers as the materials are also not taught in the correspondent course, PHYS2022.
